awd_titl_txt: Characterization of Antarctic Firn by Multi-Frequency Passive Remote Sensing from Space
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will test the hypothesis that physical and thermal properties of Antarctic firn--partially compacted granular snow in an intermediate stage between snow and glacier ice--can be remotely measured from space. Although these properties, such as internal temperature, density, grain size, and layer thickness, are highly relevant to studies of Antarctic climate, ice-sheet dynamics, and mass balance, their measurement currently relies on sparse in-situ surveys under challenging weather conditions. Sensors on polar-orbiting satellites can observe the entire Antarctic every few days during their years-long lifetime. Consequently, the approaches developed in this study, when coupled with the advancing technologies of small and low-cost CubeSats, aim to contribute to Antarctic science and lead to cost-effective, convenient, and accurate long-term analyses of the Antarctic system while reducing the human footprint on the continent. Moreover, the project will be solely based on publicly-available datasets; thus, while contributing to interdisciplinary undergraduate and graduate research and education at the grantee's institution, the project will also encourage engagement of citizen scientists through its website. 

The overarching goal of this project is to characterize Antarctic firn layers in terms of their thickness, physical temperature, density, and grain size through multi-frequency microwave radiometer measurements from space. Electromagnetic penetration depth changes with frequency in ice; thus, multi-frequency radiometers are able to profile firn layer properties versus depth. To achieve its objective, the project will utilize the Global Precipitation Measurement (GPM) satellite constellation as a single multi-frequency microwave radiometer system with 11 frequency channels observing the Antarctic Ice Sheet. Archived in-situ measurements of Antarctic firn density, grain size, temperature, and layer thickness will be collected and separated into training and test datasets. Microwave emissions simulated using the training data will be compared to GPM constellation measurements to evaluate and improve state-of-the-art forward microwave emission models. Based on these models, the project will develop numerical retrieval algorithms for the thermal and physical properties of Antarctic firn. Results of retrievals will be validated using the test dataset, and uncertainty and error analyses will be conducted. Lastly, changes in the thermal and physical characteristics of Antarctic firn will be examined through long-term retrieval studies exploiting GPM constellation measurements.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has aimed to test the hypothesis that the Antarctic firn, partially compacted granular snow in an intermediate stage between snow and glacier ice, can be characterized in terms of its subsurface physical and thermal properties using remote sensing measurements performed by space-borne microwave radiometers, i.e., instruments deployed on satellites which collect the radiant energy emitted from the Antarctic Ice Sheet.

Considering the Antarctic firn as a planar layered medium, the project team have described the firn subsurface density and temperature profiles versus depth as parametric functions with multiple variables and managed to simulate top of the atmosphere microwave radiations through improved forward electromagnetic emission models across a wide frequency spectrum from 6.9 GHz to 91.665 GHz. These simulations have been validated with multi-frequency radiometer measurements performed by the Global Precipitation Measurement (GPM) satellite constellation. Moreover, it has been observed that measurements at different frequencies probe different depths of the Antarctic firn as the electromagnetic penetration depth decreases with frequency; thus, lower frequencies are sensitive to deep firn properties, such as deep ice temperature and density fluctuations due to internal ice layerings, whereas higher frequencies reflect the features of the near-surface firn such as seasonal temperature variations and the rate of firn densification.

Utilizing these findings, a large set of simulated radiation datasets have been generated as functions of frequency and month of the year by varying the abovementioned ice properties. Focusing on the Concordia station, where in-situ measurements regarding the firn properties are abundant, these datasets have been matched with the GPM satellite measurements to retrieve the firn density and temperature parameter values. It has been shown that seasonal changes in the surface firn temperatures and firn density fluctuations can be accurately estimated using the multi-frequency GPM measurements whereas substantial errors have been observed in deep firn temperature and densification factor values. Further analyses revealed that these errors are due to non-uniqueness of the retrieval problem and can be mitigated by constraining the parameter values with ancillary data from other instruments such as ground penetrating radars.

Firn density and temperature profiles provide valuable information regarding the past and present Antarctic climate as well as the physics and dynamics of the Antarctic system such as ice flow rate and ice-sheet mass balance. Current studies on these subjects mainly rely on costly, difficult, and sparse in-situ measurements. This study, on the other hand, have demonstrated that polar orbiting satellite-based microwave radiometers which can observe the entire Antarctic every few days during their decades-long lifetime have the potential to enable cost-effective, convenient, and accurate long-term analyses of the Antarctic System.

The results of the project, which have been reported through several journal and conference articles and presentations, will have considerable scientific impacts as it directly serves international efforts to obtain information from the polar regions regarding the Earth system while minimizing the human footprint in these vulnerable parts of our planet. Moreover, this research has contributed to the development of the PI, Dr. Aksoy, as an early career investigator and educator pursuing interdisciplinary research and teaching efforts in Electrical Engineering and Earth Sciences, as well as to the training of multiple graduate and undergraduate students at the University at Albany.
